description: A species in the onion genus, Allium. It is native to Central Asia and northeastern Iran and has long been a common seasoning worldwide, with a history of several thousand years of human consumption and use.
healthBenefits: Contains allicin, a sulfur compound with potent medicinal properties, including immune-boosting effects.
May help lower blood pressure and cholesterol levels, supporting heart health.
Traditionally used for its antibacterial and antiviral effects.

potentialAllergies.name: Garlic Intolerance/Allergy
potentialAllergies.details: Can cause digestive issues (heartburn, gas) in some individuals. True allergy is rare but can cause skin reactions or more severe symptoms.

potentialAllergies.name: Blood Thinning
potentialAllergies.details: Garlic can have blood-thinning properties; individuals on anticoagulant medication should consult their doctor before consuming large amounts or supplements.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Planting: Plant individual cloves (pointy end up) in autumn or early spring.
2. Soil: Well-drained, fertile soil rich in organic matter with a pH of 6.0-7.0.
3. Spacing: Space cloves 4-6 inches apart, 2 inches deep.
4. Watering: Water regularly, especially during bulb development. Reduce watering as harvest approaches.
5. Weeding: Keep weed-free.
6. Harvesting: Harvest when lower leaves turn yellow/brown and begin to dry. Gently dig up bulbs and cure in a shady, airy spot for a few weeks.
growthDuration: About 8-9 months if planted in autumn; shorter for spring planting.
sustainabilityTips: Store whole garlic bulbs in a cool, dark, dry place with good air circulation (not in the refrigerator).
Once a clove is broken from the bulb, use remaining cloves within a week or two.
Garlic scapes (flower stalks of hardneck varieties) are edible and delicious.
carbonFootprintInfo: Generally low, around 0.4-0.6 kg CO2e/kg for field-grown garlic.

staticRecipes.name: Roasted Garlic
staticRecipes.description: Roasting garlic transforms it into a sweet, creamy, and spreadable delight.
steps: Slice off the top 1/4 to 1/2 inch of the garlic head(s) to expose the tops of the cloves.
Place garlic head(s) on a piece of aluminum foil. Drizzle with olive oil and sprinkle with salt and pepper.
Wrap the garlic loosely in the foil.
Roast for 30-45 minutes, or until the cloves are very soft and light golden brown.
Let cool slightly. Squeeze the roasted garlic cloves out of their skins. Use as a spread, in dips, or add to dishes.

staticRecipes.name: Garlic Butter Shrimp Scampi
staticRecipes.description: A quick and flavorful pasta dish or appetizer featuring shrimp cooked in garlic butter sauce.
ingredients: 1 lb large shrimp, peeled and deveined
1/4 cup dry white wine or chicken broth
Cooked pasta (e.g., linguine) or crusty bread for serving
steps: Melt butter in a large skillet over medium heat. Add minced garlic and red pepper flakes (if using); cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant (do not brown garlic).
Add shrimp to the skillet in a single layer. Cook for 1-2 minutes per side, until pink and opaque.
Pour in white wine or broth and lemon juice. Bring to a simmer and cook for 1-2 minutes more, until sauce slightly reduces.
Remove from heat. Stir in chopped parsley.
Serve immediately over cooked pasta or with crusty bread for dipping.

staticRecipes.name: Aglio e Olio (Garlic and Oil Pasta)
staticRecipes.description: A simple yet classic Italian pasta dish where garlic and olive oil are the stars.
ingredients: 1/2 cup good quality extra virgin olive oil
1/2 tsp red pepper flakes (or to taste)
steps: Cook pasta according to package directions until al dente. Reserve about 1 cup of pasta water before draining.
While pasta is cooking, heat olive oil in a large skillet over medium-low heat. Add sliced garlic and red pepper flakes.
Cook slowly, stirring frequently, until garlic is lightly golden and fragrant (about 3-5 minutes). Be careful not to burn the garlic, as it will become bitter.
Add cooked and drained pasta to the skillet with the garlic and oil. Add a few tablespoons of the reserved pasta water to help create a light sauce.
Toss well to coat the pasta. Stir in chopped parsley and season with salt.
Serve immediately, topped with grated Parmesan cheese if desired.
